front.title: Linkset: A Link Relation Type for Link Sets

abstract.t: This specification defines the "linkset" link relation type that can be used to link to a resource that provides a set of links.

note.title: Note to Readers
note.t: Please discuss this draft on the ART mailing list ().
Online access to all versions and files is available on GitHub ().

section.title: Introduction
section.t: A hypermedia resource typically conveys typed Web Links as an inherent part of the resource's representation , for example, using the <link> element for HTML representations, or the "Link" header field in HTTP response headers for representations of any media type. Cases exist in which providing links by value is impractical or impossible. In these cases, an approach to provide links by reference is desired. This specification defines the "linkset" relation type that allows doing so.

section.title: Terminology
section.t: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in RFC 2119 .

section.title: Link
section.t: A "link" relates resources by virtue of connecting them in a way that is meaningful to applications. Links can have any number of participating resources, but in most scenarios on the Web, and in popular link models, they often have exactly two participating resources. In addition, links almost always have directionality, meaning that participating resources play roles in a link and the link is intended to be traversed in a particular way.

section.title: Source Resource
section.t: For directional links (i.e., the vast majority of links on the Web and in link models), the "source resource" is a resource that is intended to be the start point of link traversal. Depending on the scenario, the source resource can be a URI-identified resource, or it can be a fragment of a URI-identified resource.

section.title: Target Resource
section.t: For directional links (i.e., the vast majority of links on the Web and in link models), the "target resource" is a resource that is intended to be the end point of link traversal. Depending on the scenario, the source resource can be a URI-identified resource, or it can be a fragment of a URI-identified resource.

section.title: Link Anchor
section.t: A "link anchor" is any resource that is participating in a link. In directional link models, a resource can be anchored as "source resource" or as "target resource". While this matters in terms of how a link is intended to be traversed, both roles have the same fundamental meaning that the resource is participating in a link.

section.title: Linked Resource
section.t: Any resource that is participating in a link (as "source resource" or as "target resource") is a "linked resource". When attempting to understand how a resource is participating in links (i.e., how it is linked), its participation in links as both "source resource" and "target resource" roles is significant.

section.title: Third-Party Links
section.t: Cases exist in which a service other than the one providing a resource is expected to provide links for that resource. This "third-party link resource" is hosted by a link server that may be managed by the same custodian as the responding resource, or by a third party. In order for the responding server to provide up-to-date and complete links about its resources, it would need to obtain them from the link server, and embed them in the resource representations prior to responding to a client. Doing so increases latency and load, which may be unnecessary if a client is not intent on consuming links. Providing links by reference, instead of by value, removes this additional latency by avoiding server-to-server communication required to obtain links.

section.title: Large Number of Links
section.t: When conveying links in the HTTP "Link" header, cases exist in which the size of the HTTP response header becomes unpredictable. This is, for example, the case when links are determined dynamically dependent on a range of contextual factors. It is possible to statically configure a web server to correctly handle large HTTP response headers by specifying an upper boundary for their size. But when the number of links and the amount of bytes required for each is unpredictable, estimating a reliable upper boundary is challenging. While HTTP defines error codes related to excess communication by the user agent ("413 Request Entity Too Large" and "414 Request-URI Too Long"), no error codes are defined to indicate that a response header exceeds the upper boundary that can be handled by the server. As a result, applications take counter measures aimed at controlling the size of the HTTP "Link" header, for example, by limiting the links they provide to those with select relation types, thereby limiting the value of the HTTP "Link" header to clients. Providing links by reference, instead of by value, overcomes challenges related to the unpredictable nature of the extent of HTTP "Link" headers.

section.title: Link Relation for Linking to Link Sets
section.t: The "linkset" link relation type is used by a resource to link to a resource that provides a set of links. Typically the Context IRI of these links is the URI of the responding resource but links with other Context IRIs MAY be provided.

The media type of the link set that is accessible via the Target IRI of a link with the "linkset" relation type is not constrained, but the representation of the link set MUST allow a user-agent to unambiguously determine the Context IRI of each provided link.

More than one link with a "linkset" relation type MAY be provided. Multiple such links can refer to the same set of links expressed using different representations, or to different link sets. The use of a link with the "linkset" relation type does not preclude the provision of links with other relation types, i.e. it is possible for a resource to combine both inline and out-of-line links.

section.title: Examples
section.t: shows a client issuing an HTTP head request for resource http://example.org/resource1.

figure.title: Client HTTP HEAD Request
figure.artwork: HEAD /resource1 HTTP/1.1 Host: example.org Connection: close

section.t: Sections and show possible responses to the HTTP request of that include the provision of a link with the "linkset" relation type, as well as a client following those links to retrieve a link set.

section.title: Link Set Serialized as application/link-format
section.t: shows the response to the HEAD request of . The response contains a "Link" header with a link that uses the "linkset" relation type. It indicates that links are provided by another resource http://example.com/links/http://example.org/resource, which uses the media type application/link-format . Using this media type, links are serialized in the same manner as the payload of the "Link" header, which lowers the barrier for user-agents that are already able to consume HTTP links.

figure.title: Response to HTTP HEAD on Resource
figure.artwork: HTTP/1.1 200 OK Date: Mon, 28 Nov 2016 14:37:51 GMT Server: Apache-Coyote/1.1 Link: <http://example.com/links/http://example.org/resource1> ; rel="linkset" ; type="application/link-format" Content-Length: 5214 Content-Type: text/html;charset=utf-8 Connection: close

section.t: shows the client issuing an HTTP GET request against the Target IRI of the link with the "linkset" relation type shown in .

figure.title: Client HTTP GET on application/link-format Link Set Resource
figure.artwork: GET /links/http://example.org/resource1 HTTP/1.1 Host: example.com Accept: application/link-format Connection: close

section.t: shows response to the HTTP GET request of . As can be seen from this example, in order to support an unambiguous determination of the Context IRI of each link, an approach is taken whereby an "anchor" attribute is provided for each link. For most (but not all) links, the Context IRI is the resource that provided the link with the "linkset" relation type, namely http://example.org/resource1.
